context: Although no control patients per se were studied, the observation that no change in the level of ethane was detected as a function of the surgical procedure in case no. 3 suggests that the contributions from ischemia and reperfusion injury to lipid peroxidation is not significant with the short cross-clamping time of 18 minutes. In the other patients the time of cross-clamping was much longer, and lipid peroxidation was detected. The earlier appearance of ethane in case 7 may be explained by the fact that in this case only the bypass pump was not used. The lipid peroxidation documented by the elaboration of ethane is one measure of lipid damage caused by reperfusion. The levels of exhaled ethane at various points in the surgical procedures were comparable to those previously reported,  5 although the overall increases in ethane levels were less than the increases observed at reperfusion when a human liver was transplanted. 4 An order of magnitude estimate based on the amount of ethane measured indicates that roughly 50 to 100 nmol lipids must be peroxidized to provide the peak detected after reperfusion. The functional significance of the reperfusion damage that this represents is dependent on several factors that are not presently understood.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethane is presented as a byproduct of lipid peroxidation, which occurs during ischemia and reperfusion injury. The study indicates that the levels of ethane detected correlate with the extent of lipid damage caused by reperfusion, suggesting that ethane can serve as a marker for lipid peroxidation. The absence of ethane changes in one case implies minimal lipid peroxidation, while its presence in others indicates significant lipid damage associated with longer cross-clamping times during surgery.
